title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary focus of the speaker's research in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: Studying the impact of climate change on urban wildlife

options.label: B
options.text: Investigating the evolution of native species in urban environments

options.label: C
options.text: Examining the effects of pollution on human health

options.label: D
options.text: Analyzing the behavior of invasive species in the city

multiple-choice.question: Which species is used as a model to understand how species adapt to urban environments?
What is the purpose of sequencing thousands of genes from city mice and comparing them to country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify genetic differences between the two populations

options.label: B
options.text: To study the impact of urbanization on mouse behavior

options.label: C
options.text: To develop new methods for tracking mouse populations

options.label: D
options.text: To investigate the effects of climate change on mouse evolution

multiple-choice.question: What is a Manhattan plot, and what does it represent?

options.label: A
options.text: A graph showing the population size of mice in different parks

options.label: B
options.text: A diagram illustrating the genetic differences between city and country mice

options.label: C
options.text: A chart displaying the distribution of mouse species in New York City

options.label: D
options.text: A map showing the location of mouse habitats in the city

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the "mixed-up colors" in the middle of the figure showing the genetic differences between mice in different parks?

options.label: A
options.text: It indicates that the mice in those parks are genetically identical

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that the mice in those parks are adapting to different environments

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that the mice in those parks are still connected by strips of forest

options.label: D
options.text: It implies that the mice in those parks are experiencing genetic drift

multiple-choice.question: How do changes in a single base pair of a gene affect the organism?

options.label: A
options.text: They have no impact on the organism's biology

options.label: B
options.text: They can change the structure and function of a protein

options.label: C
options.text: They only affect the organism's behavior

options.label: D
options.text: They are always beneficial to the organism

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the ability of an organism to survive and reproduce in its environment?
How do the speaker and their colleagues track the movement and behavior of coyotes in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: By observing them directly in the wild

options.label: C
options.text: By analyzing DNA samples from coyote scat

options.label: D
options.text: By conducting surveys of local residents

multiple-choice.question: What is the likely reason for the genetic differences between mice in different parks in New York City?
What is the speaker's ultimate goal in studying the evolution of native species in urban environments?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new methods for tracking wildlife populations

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how species adapt to urban environments

options.label: C
options.text: To predict the impact of climate change on urban ecosystems

options.label: D
options.text: To inform conservation efforts in urban areas

title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the global movement of goods and services that has led to the availability of a wide range of products from different countries?
Who is credited with making globalization a reality in our lives?
What was Malcolm McLean's occupation when he first thought of the idea of containerization?
What problem did Malcolm McLean face while delivering cotton bales to a pier in Hoboken, New Jersey?

options.label: A
options.text: He got lost on the way

options.label: B
options.text: He had to wait for a long time for the goods to be unloaded

options.label: C
options.text: He had to pay a high toll

multiple-choice.question: What was the traditional method of shipping general non-bulk cargo before containerization?
How did Malcolm McLean's idea of containerization revolutionize the shipping industry?

options.label: A
options.text: It increased the cost of shipping

options.label: B
options.text: It reduced the time it took to load and unload ships

options.label: C
options.text: It decreased the number of goods that could be shipped

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Malcolm McLean's first container ship?
What was the impact of containerization on the global marketplace?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduced the variety of goods available

options.label: B
options.text: It increased the cost of goods

options.label: C
options.text: It made it possible to move cargo at minimal cost

multiple-choice.question: How long did it take Malcolm McLean to turn his idea of containerization into a reality?
What was the result of Malcolm McLean's innovation in the shipping industry?

title: Poetic stickup: Put the financial aid in the bag - Carvens Lissaint

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's primary goal in the poem?

options.label: B
options.text: To get financial aid for education

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's tone in the poem?
What does the speaker compare the struggle for financial aid to?
Who does the speaker mention as an example of someone who fought for education?
What does the speaker accuse the financial aid system of doing?

options.label: B
options.text: Providing fair and equal access to education

options.label: C
options.text: Strangling the life out of their bank statement

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's attitude towards debt?

options.label: A
options.text: They see it as a necessary evil

options.label: C
options.text: They are angry about being forced into debt

options.label: D
options.text: They think it's a good thing

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker compare lecture halls to?
What does the speaker think is the purpose of the financial aid system?

options.label: A
options.text: To help students achieve their goals

options.label: B
options.text: To provide fair and equal access to education

options.label: C
options.text: To keep students in debt and psychologically feeble

multiple-choice.question: Who does the speaker mention as an example of someone who is suffering due to lack of access to education?
What is the speaker's final plea to the financial aid system?

options.label: C
options.text: To put the money in the bag

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: What is the phrase that Dorothy repeats in the scene from "The Wizard of Oz"?
According to the transcript, why did L. Frank Baum likely choose simple words for Dorothy's phrase?

options.label: B
options.text: He wanted to confuse his readers

options.label: C
options.text: He knew that bigger words aren't always better

options.label: D
options.text: He was trying to be lazy

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript regarding word choice?

options.label: A
options.text: Using complex vocabulary is always the best choice

options.label: B
options.text: Using simple words is only for children's literature

options.label: C
options.text: Bigger words are not always better and may not be understood

options.label: D
options.text: Writers should never use a thesaurus

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion on using complex vocabulary in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: It's always necessary for good writing

options.label: B
options.text: It's only necessary for academic writing

options.label: C
options.text: It's not necessary if it's not understood by the audience

multiple-choice.question: Who is mentioned as an example of someone who might have used complex vocabulary in a famous phrase?
According to the transcript, what is the relationship between the reading level of literature and the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: All literature should be written at a fourth-grade reading level

options.label: B
options.text: The reading level of literature should match the audience's expectations

options.label: C
options.text: The reading level of literature is not important

options.label: D
options.text: The reading level of literature should always be complex

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice to writers regarding word choice?

options.label: A
options.text: Use the most complex vocabulary possible

options.label: B
options.text: Use a thesaurus to find big words

options.label: C
options.text: Save your "money" and use simple words

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion on the importance of brevity in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Brevity is not important in writing

options.label: B
options.text: Brevity is only important in certain types of writing

options.label: C
options.text: Brevity is the most important aspect of writing

options.label: D
options.text: Brevity is the "bread and butter" of writing

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the challenge that writers face in terms of their audience's attention span?

options.label: A
options.text: The audience's attention span is increasing

options.label: B
options.text: The audience's attention span is staying the same

options.label: C
options.text: The audience's attention span is decreasing across generations

options.label: D
options.text: The audience's attention span is not important

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's suggestion for what to do with "10-dollar words"?

options.label: A
options.text: Use them as much as possible

options.label: C
options.text: Save your money and buy a Scrabble board

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a partnership between two different species where both depend on each other?
Which bird species is involved in a symbiotic relationship with the whitebark pine tree?
What is the primary role of the whitebark pine tree in the ecosystem?

options.label: B
options.text: Feeding the forest with its cones

multiple-choice.question: How do squirrels contribute to the dispersal of whitebark pine seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: By eating the seeds and then depositing them in new locations

options.label: B
options.text: By gnawing cones from the upper branches, causing them to fall to the ground

options.label: C
options.text: By burying the seeds in middens

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way Clark's nutcrackers store seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They store seeds in their nests

options.label: B
options.text: They store seeds in a pouch in their throat

options.label: C
options.text: They store seeds in underground burrows

options.label: D
options.text: They store seeds in tree cavities

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers remember the location of their cached seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: By using landmarks on the landscape

options.label: B
options.text: By relying on their sense of smell

options.label: C
options.text: By creating a mental map of the area

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the seeds that Clark's nutcrackers do not retrieve from their caches?

options.label: A
options.text: They are eaten by other animals

options.label: C
options.text: They become new whitebark pine trees

multiple-choice.question: How have Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pine trees evolved to suit each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Clark's nutcrackers have developed short, pointed beaks, and whitebark pine trees have developed downward-sweeping branches

options.label: B
options.text: Clark's nutcrackers have developed long, tough beaks, and whitebark pine trees have developed upward-sweeping branches

options.label: C
options.text: Clark's nutcrackers have developed strong legs, and whitebark pine trees have developed deep roots

options.label: D
options.text: Clark's nutcrackers have developed sharp talons, and whitebark pine trees have developed thick bark

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the symbiotic relationship between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pine trees benefits both species?

options.label: A
options.text: Clark's nutcrackers receive food, and whitebark pine trees receive protection from herbivores

options.label: B
options.text: Clark's nutcrackers receive shelter, and whitebark pine trees receive nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: Clark's nutcrackers receive seeds, and whitebark pine trees receive dispersal of their seeds

options.label: D
options.text: Clark's nutcrackers receive nesting sites, and whitebark pine trees receive pollination

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of the symbiotic relationship between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pine trees to the ecosystem as a whole?

title: How many universes are there? - Chris Anderson

multiple-choice.question: How many Earths can fit inside the sun?
Approximately how many stars are in the Milky Way galaxy?
If each star in the Milky Way galaxy was the size of a grain of sand, how large of an area would it cover?
What is the estimated number of galaxies detectable by our telescopes?
According to string theory, how many universes could make up the multiverse?
What is the concept of the multiverse in physics?

options.label: A
options.text: A single universe with multiple dimensions

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple universes with different properties and laws

options.label: C
options.text: A universe with infinite space-time continuum

options.label: D
options.text: A universe with only one set of physical laws

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea behind the concept of parallel universes in quantum theory?

options.label: A
options.text: Multiple universes with different properties and laws

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple universes with the same properties and laws

options.label: C
options.text: Universes that exist in different dimensions

options.label: D
options.text: Universes that are spawned every moment with different outcomes

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated size of the space-time continuum according to some physicists?
What is the range of possible answers to the question of how many universes there are?
What is the current state of agreement among scientists on the question of how many universes there are?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a consensus on a single answer

options.label: C
options.text: There is no agreement, with a range of possible answers

options.label: D
options.text: The question is no longer relevant in modern physics

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

multiple-choice.question: What did Richard Feynman's father tell him was the reason the ball went to the back of the wagon?
Who is credited with proving that the Earth is spherical using the observation of the Earth's shadow on the Moon?
What was the key fact that Eratosthenes used to calculate the circumference of the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: The distance between Alexandria and Swenet

options.label: B
options.text: The angle of the sun's shadow in Alexandria

options.label: C
options.text: The diameter of the well in Swenet

options.label: D
options.text: The time it took to travel from Alexandria to Swenet

multiple-choice.question: How did Eratosthenes calculate the circumference of the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: By multiplying the distance between Alexandria and Swenet by the angle of the sun's shadow

options.label: B
options.text: By dividing the distance between Alexandria and Swenet by the angle of the sun's shadow

options.label: D
options.text: By extrapolating from the circumference of a circle

multiple-choice.question: Who invented the word "geography"?
What was Armand Fizeau's specialty in physics?

options.label: C
options.text: Refining and confirming other people's results

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of Galileo's experiment with the lamps?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure the speed of light

options.label: B
options.text: To measure the speed of sound

options.label: C
options.text: To prove that light has a discernible speed

options.label: D
options.text: To disprove that light has a discernible speed

multiple-choice.question: How did Fizeau solve the problem of measuring the speed of light?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a toothed wheel to send discrete pulses of light

options.label: B
options.text: By using a mirror to reflect light over a long distance

options.label: C
options.text: By using a beam splitter to divide the light into two paths

options.label: D
options.text: By using a spectrometer to analyze the light

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Fizeau's experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: He calculated the speed of light to within 10% of its actual value

options.label: B
options.text: He calculated the speed of light to within 2% of its actual value

options.label: C
options.text: He proved that light has no discernible speed

options.label: D
options.text: He disproved that light has a discernible speed

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the speaker's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: That science is a closed, black box

options.label: B
options.text: That science is an open field that anyone can explore

options.label: C
options.text: That only geniuses can make scientific discoveries

options.label: D
options.text: That science is too complicated for ordinary people to understand
